receiver-org.narrative: Fundación Equipo de Reflexión, Investigación y Comunicación /Radio Progreso

title.narrative: Holistic Quality Care for People Living with HIV and HIV Prevention with Children in the Sula Valley

description.narrative: This project is the continuation of HON065. Honduras is one of the poorest countries in Latin America, with the largest concentration of HIV and AIDS in Central America. Puerta Abierta (Open Door) works with people living with HIV and AIDS (PLWHA) and their families in conditions of poverty and inequality. Puerta Abierta was created in 1997 by the Catholic Congregation of the Vincentian Fathers to respond to the needs of PLWHA in the Sula Valley, in which San Pedro Sula is located. Their aim is to provide a holistic and effective response to the HIV and AIDS pandemic in San Pedro Sula, opening coordination spaces at Church level and with other local and national institutions and providing processes of holistic care to people with HIV and their families - medical, psychological and social care -; home visits; education - and preventive work with PLWHAS, parish communities and general public. Activities focus on the personal, family, social, psychological and spiritual aspects of living with HIV and AIDS, with both formal and non-formal education components. The formal component includes educational classes and medical care, including the provision of some drugs where needs are identified; the non-formal components include more varied activities. Examples are educational-entertainment activities including exhibits and games in schools and a Puerta Abierta programme (called Children’s Window - Ventana del Niño), awareness raising talks in classrooms in schools and in parishes. Activities for adults include workshops and training sessions with PLWHAs. And the provision of grants to families of PLWHA to allow for children to attend school, covering school fees and materials, and food supplies. The project also supports the voice of PLWHA in Honduran society. They assert people’s rights within the public health system when they are not provided with treatment. It also includes networking with other organisations providing support to PLWHAs. Now, in the context of COVID-19

title.narrative: Immediate life-saving humanitarian response among marginal and excluded population in Assam - India

description.narrative:
Since May 2020 Assam has been experiencing severe rainfall, triggering massive floods and landslides affecting 26,31,343 people in 2525 villages under 26 districts out of 33 districts in Assam and causing 104 deaths. The release of excess water from the hydro project dams in Bhutan, Arunachal and Nagaland have further aggravated the situation. The raging water of Brahmaputra and its tributaries have crossed the danger mark in several areas, breaching earthen embankments and inundating villages.
Based on identified gaps, Caritas India proposes a priority-based, life-saving humanitarian assistance within the sectors of: 1) Food Security and Livelihood through Unconditional cash transfer and 2) Hygiene. Together with their partner Guwahati Gana Seva Society and Women Development centre, the response will support targeted beneficiaries focusing on an inclusive response approach) with 1) unconditional cash transfers to contribute to food and livelihood security to 600 HH and 2) increased awareness on hygiene and Covid 19 along with hygiene kit distribution to 1000 HH.
The response will reach out to the most vulnerable 1600 HH across 2 Gram Panchayats and 14 villages with unconditional cash transfer (food security and livelihood) of 3800 INR for 30 days for a family of 5 and hygiene kits.

title.narrative: Rapid Response for Western Sulawesi Earthquake

description.narrative:
On 15/1/2021, a 6.2 earthquake hit Western Sulawesi severely impacting Mamuju district. killing at least 91 people and injuring hundreds, prompting landslides and destroying houses. Total number of people affected: 20,448. The epicenter of the quake was six kilometres north-east of Majene city at a depth of 10 kilometres.
KARINA and the diocese of Makassar conducted a needs assessment among 32 affected groups identifying the main needs: -Food -Access to clean water -Unavailability of public lavatories -Challenges around evacuation points due to Covid-19.
The aim of this rapid response is to provide life-saving essential items to the affected people together with support around COVID 19 protocols.

title.narrative: Telemedicine: Supporting Caritas Jordan in response to COVID-19

description.narrative:
COVID-19 has been spreading in Jordan since the beginning of March 2020. Restrictions imposed by the Jordanian Government following the COVID-19 outbreak have severely impacted the ability of refugees to access health care services, and at the same time, those services which are available are hugely overstretched. Due to restrictions, Caritas clinics are operating on a reduced capacity, leaving thousands of refugees without access to healthcare and medications. Although Caritas Jordan health clinics are now partially functioning, clinic staff are overloaded and not able to accommodate the full needs of the refugee population.
This project will fund the installation of a Telemedicine service (calling centre) to provide essential health services for refugees during the pandemic and beyond, and will include the following sub-services: GP and Specialist consultation, Pharmaceutical prescription, Nutrition Advice and Emergency Referral cases. The Telemedicine service will increase access to CJ's health services, reaching more people and easing the burden of existing health facilities, while complying with government regulations and ensuring the safety of both Caritas staff and refugee communities. It will also reduce the number of people arriving at the health centres thereby reducing the risk of the virus spreading, and is also a way of ensuring that people living in isolated areas or neighbourhoods that have been blocked off by GoJ can still access essential health services.
Funds will be spent on the following: - Setting up the Telemedicine calling centre system - Laptops for operators - Antivirus for calling centre server - CRM licence

title.narrative: Supporting communities on improving access to safe drinking water in Pouk district, Siem Reap provin

description.narrative:
The project is to support disadvantaged people in Lvea and Trei Nhor communes, Pouk district, Siem Reap province, to enhance living conditions through better access to safe drinking water and proper hygiene practices. It is a complemented project to target communities whom are being supported by one of CAFOD partners, Srer Khmer (SK). Key lesson learnt from SK’s project implementation is that community people are facing immediate needs on accessing safe water for their daily consumption and the limitation knowledge of both local authorities and community people on safe drinking water. In Thveas village, Trei Nhor commune, there is a bottled water purification system 20L handed over from Habitat for Humanity which found with need of supports on the establishment of water management committee and capacity building in business and marketing operation to make it re-function and respond to community needs on accessing safe water. Also, With outbreaking of COVID-19 pandemic, there is a concern about people health which would be inflection of Coronavirus due to limiatation of getting information on Covid-19 implication, precausion guidance and hygiene practices. All these challenges are critically affected people livelihood conditions.
To support communities to overcome these issues, the project has been designed by conducting a feasibility study, all different groups of community people have been engaged through number of meetings, focused group discussion, and in-depth interview to discuss on situation analysis, resources mapping, and identify alternative actions to improve the current situation. The project objectives are: - To increase knowledge of community groups and local authorities on safe drinking water and proper hygiene practices through adoption of water safety plan. - To increase communities’ access to safe drinking water through upgrading water facilities and increased capacity of commune and village focal points to sustainably manage the water purification system 20L (handed over from Habitat for Humanity). The project is proposed to work complementarily with targeted villages under Srer Khmer and to contribute to community sustainability after the project of SK would be phased out by 2022, by forming local authorities, commune focal points, village focal points and community leaders to be a water management committee and to involve in all project phases. SK is focusing on farming capacity and livelihood development, and at the meantime, RWC’s project is on safe water management and improvement of hygiene practice- It is a key sustainability of project with the strategic approach of integration between livelihood and WASH to increase community quality of life. The project has also supported communities with recent outbreaking of COVID-19 pandemic through conducting people awarenee and knowledges on Covid-19 precaution and hygiene promotion in alignment with the government IEC materials and guideline.

title.narrative: Covid-19 emergency response and recovery for poor communities in Pursat and Banteay Mean Chey

description.narrative:
The project is to reach out to respond to needs of the affected people, mainly youth and young adults, who had returned to their villages and are unemployed as a result of Covid-19. Over 800,000 Cambodian migrant workers from Thailand alone have had to return home and have lost their incomes since March 2020. The main Covid impact on Cambodia is economic as it is heavily dependent on garment industry which has been hit hard by cancellations/non-payment of orders. Many former garment workers mostly young people have also returned to their hometowns increasing burdens on farmer families to find food to feed all their members.
Partner has conducted impact survey in target communities to understand real issues and needs of community people. Interviews and meetings were conducted with all groups of people, local authorities, youth and young adults migrants who have returned home, poor farmers, school directors, and students, for providing them the opportunity to discuss about challenges, to find a solution and to seek any alternative way to support each other.
The project objectives are: - To support farmers for creation Self-Help Group's fund and loans that can give to these affected people who are willing to get back into small and sustainable agriculture. - To provide support to farmers for setting up the SRI cultivation, chicken rearing and home gardening on their land or on hired land for youth in the communities as necessary. Instead of hiring machines, the work will have to be done manually by these affected people for which they will be paid.
This project is specifically targeting group of people those who need immediate jobs to get food and income to survive. The project will support farmers on chicken rearing, vegetable growing, hiring land for the poor to grow rice, providing some for emergency food for the poorest farmer who face food shortage, and raising people awareness on hygiene and sanitation related behavior changes to prevent Covid-19.

title.narrative: Improving access to improved water source and safe drinking water in Veal Veng district, Pursat

description.narrative: The project is complemented to one of CAFOD partner (COCD) target communities in Veal Veng district, Pursat province. The overall goal of the project is to develop more capacity and resources of most marginalised families to engage in community dialogues in order to promote development in their communities. Through COCD project implementation, it has revealed that target community people are facing immediate needs on accessing safe water for their daily consumption and the limitation knowledge of local authorities and community people on safe drinking water; while, COCD’s project has focused on livelihood development specifically. In late September to October 2020, these communities were faced flash flooding that caused water system from waterfall, which is a main water source for people in Tumpor community, was damaged and it caused people lack of safe drinking water and poor hygiene practices. COCD and RWC have discussed with key informants in communities on current situations, challenges and discuss for solutions for improvement of community health through drinking safe water and proper hygiene practices in which an entry point would be focused on improving water supply system in community and building community committee and people on safe drinking water management. On the other hand, to deeply understand community challenges and to response to people needs, partner has conducted a feasibility study by involving from all community groups of people to ensure that the project has responded to community needs and reached to marginalized groups. Two specific objectives are proposed: - To improve the access to clean water of poorest households through promoting active participation in water management process in order to meet their needs for better livelihoods. - To improve the capacity of water management committees on water management and to enable them to be able to support the poorest community people addressing their needs on water. Some approaches have been proposed based on community resources including: 1). upgrading households water facilities and households water treatment and safety storage, 2). upgrading local public water assets including waterfall and pond, 3) capacity improvement for water management committee, and 4) community people awareness to improve situation of accessing to drinking safe water and proper hygiene practice including the precaution of Covid-19 pandemic. To contribute to CAFOD strategy– OCH, project will demonstrate its clean technology in upgrading water assets and promotion of collection rainwater throughout community to ensure the safety, access, dignity and inclusion by targeting for poor and disadvantage peoples in the community to be supported through project. Also, the implemented project is a CAFOD’s new working approach of linking resources among our partners to support and contribute each other in order to respond immediately needs of community people.

title.narrative: Amplifying the Role of Faith Leaders to Prevent and Mitigate effects of COVID19

description.narrative:
The purpose of this project is to enable the Kenya Conference of Catholic Bishops through the National Justice and Peace Commission to: - Contribute to local and national efforts to mitigate further spread and impact of COVID-19 by implementing prevention activities ( awareness raising, advocacy etc). - Support and respond to needs arising from the COVID-19 pandemic in Kenya and Uganda, taking into consideration responses by WHO and Kenya government and other stakeholders’ responses by addressing outstand gaps. - Provide assistance to vulnerable groups that are not covered by existing responses (whether neglected communities or geographical locations).
The overall objective of the project is to save lives and alleviate suffering by delivering coordinated protection and assistance to contain spread of covid-19. This include people from hard to reach communities and informal settlements, displaced, the elderly, women and children majority of whom rely on Church support. Outcomes -Improved community and public awareness on health-promoting behaviours and combat misinformation (Changes in the wider community) -Changes and improvements in how health and social care services are planned, delivered and evaluated.

title.narrative: Marsabit County COVID-19 Preparedness and Response Project

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to enable Caritas Marsabit to save lives and alleviate suffering by contributing to prevention of COVID19 spread and mitigating its impact among most vulnerable communities in marginalized areas in Moyale and Saku sub counties of Marsabit County in Kenya Outcome: Strengthened risk communication and community engagement to mitigate the spread and impact of COVID-19 pandemic through coordinated advocacy, WASH and Resilience building for most at risk communities Outputs; -Advocacy and Coordination - Strengthened Faith leaders' Voice action to mitigate COVID-19 spread and reduce its impact for at-risk populations. This will be done through supporting the county government to equip an isolation unit at Sololo Mission Hospital in Moyale Subcounty and Food provision for 80 vulnerable households in Saku Sub County -WASH - Increased access to functional Water facilities and essential Sanitation and hygiene supplies for project participants. Activities; Activity 1: Provide food parcels to 80 households in Saku County (Jaldesa- 42 and Salesa Wako- 38) consisting of 480 people (221 men and 259 Women). Activity 2: Equip 1 COVID-19 isolation ward at Sololo hospital in Moyale Sub County to prepare to serve approx. 44,822 people (23,468 Male, 21,354 Females) residents of the subcounty. Activity 3: Equip 100 health workers, 200 volunteers, and 300 persons at risk ( with pre-existing conditions) in the community with sanitizers and face masks Activity 4: Provide handwashing facilities in the communal places in the villages and health centres targeting 4700 people

title.narrative: Building Back Better: Risk-informed COVID-19 Recovery, Rehabilitation, and Strengthening Resilience

description.narrative:
The aim of this project is to contribute to Risk-informed COVID-19 Recovery, Rehabilitation, and Strengthening Resilience to Climate Change-Related Disasters in Marsabit. this will result is increased access to water for multiple use and community resilience in prevention and response to COVID 19 Pandemic in Marsabit County. Outputs: -5 functional water facilities in Warra and Balah Villages for 503 HH -296 vulnerable households access cash programming for vulnerable HH in Warah, Kambinye, Bagasi and Urweno Villages Activities -Rehabilitation of Warra water pan and Wara underground tank -Upgrading Balah borehole with 2 troughs, taps and pipeline repair. -Provision of borehole spare parts and fuel subsidy for 3 boreholes in Thurusi, Lalesa and Balah borehole -Provision of handwashing containers to vulnerable households in Warra, Balah, Kambinye, Bagasi and Urweno villages -Cash for work will reach 103 Households for 19 days in Warra as participants in desilting Warra water pan and underground tank. -Food vouchers reaching 193 Households @ KES 4050 for a half food ration for 3 months for vulnerable HH in 3 villages of Kambinye, Bagasi and Urweno for persons with special needs especially elderly, with critical terminal illness and people with disabilities. -Cash grant to establish and empower 3 women groups to set up soap making business in Warrah, Balah and Kambinye. Items will include hand washing liquid soap, and surface/household cleaning detergents.
Caritas Marsabit identified the above gaps and activities in consultation with community structures through parishes and the county steering coordination mechanism. Project design, implementation and monitoring tools and process take cognisance of protection principles and adherence to core humanitarian standards. A community project specific implementation committee and feedback handling committees per each of the 2 sub counties have been initiated at project design consultation stage.

title.narrative: Supporting households affected by the Beirut Port Explosion 2020

description.narrative:
The huge explosion at Beirut’s port is a crippling blow to a country that had been reeling from a political and financial crisis, a depreciating currency and the Covid-19 pandemic. Economic damage from the blast is estimated in the billions of dollars. The massive explosion on 4th August 2020 that hit Beirut port and a big part of the city killed more than 154 people, with more than 6,000 wounded and dozens of persons missing. The homes of more than 300,000 families were partially or totally destroyed and their inhabitants displaced.
The overall goal of the project is to support the households affected by the Beirut port explosion by providing unconditional and multi-purpose cash assistance. To achieve this goal the project intends to provide unconditional cash assistance of an amount USD 100 per family per month for a period of two months.
January-March 2021 additional support (£60,000) will enable AN to reach an additional 325 HH with 200 USD. Each HH will received USD 200 in one installment.

title.narrative: Beirut Blast Response: EA21/2020

description.narrative:
On August 4th 2020, a large explosion occurred in the Beirut port, killing over 175 and injuring over 6,500 people. The exact cause of the blast has been linked to 2,750 tons of confiscated ammonium nitrate.
This project will respond to the ongoing needs of those affected by the Beirut Blast, through distribution of food kits and hot meals, NFI distributions (hygiene kits and winterisation kits), distribution of solar panels, provision of medical consultation and distribution of medicines and vaccinations, distribution of PPEs and COVID-19 information.
Food Security and Nutrition: 1,200 affected Lebanese access Food Kits and 3,000 individuals access immediate Hot Meals.
Shelter and non-food items: 2,400 affected Lebanese receive Non-Food Items (NFI). 1,200 impacted Lebanese access basic rechargeable solar panels 150 Impacted Lebanese households feel safe and secure again in their own houses.
Health: 24.650 of impacted people have their medical status maintained
Education: 420 Impacted Lebanese students have access to E-learning education for the upcoming scholastic year 2020-21.
Livelihoods: 40 impacted Lebanese businesses are rehabilitated and activated

title.narrative: Support platform for formal and non-formal civil society groups

description.narrative: Lebanon is undergoing multiple crises - political deadlock and economic near-collapse on top of COVID-19 and the disastrous Beirut blast - and over half the population is now believed to be struggling to earn sufficient income to meet basic necessities. Lebanese civil society has traditionally been very dynamic; indeed the weaknesses of the state in providing basic services to the population led to the emergence of NGOs trying to offset this absence or lack of services. Following the Syria crisis, new associations or non-formal groups, were established to provide basic support to Syrian refugees in Lebanon or in Syria. Recognising that the kinds of support on offer by other INGOS were too often insufficiently tailored to smaller organisations to add real value, especially in relation to the needs of small organisations with limited financial and human resources, Mada established its platform initially in 2005 to fill the gap. CAFOD funding from 2017 enabled Mada to re-launch and reactivate its Platform, and in the changed context of the Syrian Civil War and mass influx of Syrian refugees into Lebanon, to work with both Lebanese and Syrian NGOs and non-formal groups to achieve their mission and objectives without leading to a change in the spirit, values or characteristics of these organisations. This project, which is now moving into a second phase, forms part of CAFOD's support to peace building work in Lebanon by facilitating collaboration between Lebanese and Syrian civil society groups, thereby contributing to increased social cohesion between these communities. It will also support the development and strengthening of a strong and vibrant Syrian civil society able to contribute to peace building in Syria in the future.

title.narrative: Emergency Response to Beirut Explosion-II

description.narrative:
On 4 August 2020 two explosions rocked the port of Beirut, killing over 200 people, injuring over 6,000 and leaving thousands in need of assistance. This project will aid response to the mid to longer term effects of the explosion through the following:
1. Emergency packages to 670 households: food kits, hygiene kits (along with PPE + COVID-19 awareness) and cash assistance.
2. Protection services: focused PSS sessions, mental health and PSS sessions and specialized case management services to 252 children; positive parenting sessions to 100 parents; emergency protection cash to 40 households.

title.narrative: Assistência humanitária aos deslocados de guerra de Cabo Delgado

description.narrative: The ongoing emergency has its origins in the upsurge of violence in Cabo Delgado province in northern Mozambique, which is forcing thousands of people to flee attacks by armed groups who identify themselves as Islamists in order to save their lives. According to UNHCR in February there were at least 100,000 displaced people within the province. In recent months there has been a drastic increase in the attacks started in October 2017 and perpetrated by these armed groups. The violence is spreading through the Districts of the South, causing the massive displacement of the inhabitants to the capital of the region, Pemba In the last three weeks the displaced have begun a more distant migration, arriving also in the territory of the Province of Nampula especially in the Districts situated along the main road that colleagues the North with the city of Nampula (Erati, Nacaroa, Monapo, Meconta up to the city of Nampula itself), mostly counting on the support of relatives or acquaintances or temporarily placed in reception centres (primary schools now closed by Covid-19 or administrative posts). The situation is serious: in the areas affected by the attacks, and in the area where IDPs arrive there are no conditions for humanitarian assistance. Tents, food and hygiene kits are the main material shortages. The Diocesan Caritas of Nacala operates at the level of the territory of the Diocese of Nacala which includes n. 10 Districts, namely Nacala, Nacala-a-Velha, Memba, Erati, Nacaroa, Monapo, Liupo, Mogincual, Ilha de Moçambique and Mossuril. Out of these Districts, 4 to date are hosting IDPs.

title.narrative: Melhorando a Resiliência dos deslocados de Guerra de Cabo Delgado na Província de Nampula
CRIANÇA E MULHER LIVRE DE COVID-19 – Por uma saúde e acompanhamento Inclusiva

description.narrative: On the past 30 March 2020, the first state of emergency was declared in Mozambique in response to the first cases of infection in the country. The economic instability associated to this situation pushed thousands of people, with no means to survive, to embrace informal commercial activities, estimating that only in the city of Maputo, between 25,000 and 30,000 people practice this kind of activity. According to the register of vendors at least 22,000 vendors carry out their activities in the markets, some of which are highly congested, making them a real potential focus for the spread of COVID-19. Urgent measures must therefore be taken to mitigate the possible impacts of a rapid dissemination of the Coronavirus in the markets as well as in the neighborhoods surrounding formal and informal shopping centers. On the one hand, there are in the neighborhoods and markets high numbers of children and women in vulnerable situations at risk of contamination as they try to sustain their lives through commercial exchanges in the markets and on the streets. Despite the context, fairs and markets continue to operate normally. At the same time, it is urgent to have an intervention plan to reduce the health risk of sellers, as well as users, in order to minimize COVID-19 impact on this group of people exercising this informal commercial activity in the neighbourhoods and in the Xipamanine market.

title.narrative: Mitigation of Negative Climate Change Impact and Fostering of Climate Smart Agriculture

description.narrative:
In Myanmar’s Ayerrawaddy region climate change is a major challenge for communities due to irregular or erratic rainfall, salt intrusion, floods and extreme temperatures that affect farmers as well as landless households. These negative impacts are exacerbated by the lack of knowledge on climate change and climate change adaption livelihoods, lack of environmental care education and practice, poor participation of community level governance structures, livelihoods that depend upon traditional agriculture techniques with high chemical fertilizers inputs and lack of community participation in advocacy processes. Moreover, in 2020 with the COVID 19 crisis communities are facing more difficulties related to food security, lack of income generating activities and health issues. Unemployment rates are growing, and farmers are losing their livelihood as movement restrictions have been imposed and limited their capacity to sell their products and be able to pay back their debts.
In this sense KMSS Pathein will aim to support 20 villages so farmers and communities can lead positive change processes for environmental sustainability and creation of livelihood-based agriculture opportunities that contribute to mitigate the impact of climate change. In order to do this KMSS will integrate three main components: a) creation and empowerment (knowledge, skills and capacity building) of local governance structures (Village Development Committees VDC and Self Help groups SHG) to lead development processes in their own communities; b) promotion and practice of organic farming, as an adaptation strategy to climate change and variability; c) advocacy to local government in order to align development processes as well as establishment of networks with other local actors across the region for common agenda on sustainability.

title.narrative: Responding to the food security consequences of Covid-19 in North Gorkha

description.narrative:
The mountain communities of Nepal and across the Hindu Kush Himalaya region face specific challenges due to the remoteness from road networks, accelerated climate change, food scarcity and malnutrition, poor sanitation and health, low levels of literacy, with little opportunity to generate incomes and develop livelihoods beyond subsistence farming. These challenges are likely to be exacerbated with the outbreak of the Covid-19 pandemic in Nepal, with assessments by our Trustees in Nepal suggesting that mountain communities based on subsistence farming are likely to experience food shortages, interrupted access to seeds and agricultural inputs and the danger of famine and malnutrition.
This project builds on a post-earthquake livelihoods programme in North Gorkha (2016-2021), which piloted micro-agricultural development, by modeling kitchen gardens in Tsum Nubri and the provision of monthly agricultural development training workshops to mothers’ groups in North Gorkha.

title.narrative: Sensitization on the prevention and spread of COVID-19 in Communities of Plateau and Kogi States

description.narrative: The outbreak of Corona Virus Disease (COVID-19) in Wuhan China around December 2019 has now become a global health emergency ravaging over 150 countries with more than a million people infected with the virus. The number of persons infected keeps increasing daily and fatality rate also increasing on a daily basis with over 77,000 deaths recorded globally. Nigeria recorded its first COVID- 19 case on the 27th February, 2020 and within five weeks the number of infected cases have risen to 254 from which there are 204 active cases, 44 recoveries, 6 deaths and over 5000 suspected cases spread across 17 States as at 8th April, 2020. Though there have been no confirmed case of COVID-19 thus far in Plateau and Kogi States, but then there is low level of awareness on the preventive measures among masses as social distancing, congregational gatherings, ceremonies/anniversaries, movements, poor hygiene practices are still prevalent across the State. This therefore, if not addressed timely will lead to a wide spread of the virus in the event that a confirmed case is reported. Mamong the people for preparedness and response. This is very key as it will help prevent the occurrence of the ugly situations in many developed countries such as Italy, Spain, America and many others. It is based on the above background that there is an urgent need to design strategies for sensitization on the preventive measures and good hygiene practices to curb the spread of COVID-19. This could be done through Airing of Jingles, production and distribution of handbills, flyers and provision of handwashing facilities such as buckets, soap, sanitizers to 1000 households and crowded places like motor parks and worship centres.

title.narrative: Project to curtail the spread and impact of Covid 19 in communities of Adamawa State

description.narrative: The COVID-19 pandemic is the defining global health crisis of our time. (it could be said to be the greatest challenge we have faced since World War Two). Since its emergence in China in December 2019, the virus has spread to 213 countries (including Nigeria) with the number of confirmed cases rising daily in Africa, the Americas, and Europe. Countries are racing to slow the spread of the virus by testing and treating patients, carrying out contact tracing, limiting travel, quarantining citizens, and cancelling large gatherings such as sporting events, concerts, and schools. The wide increasing spread of Coronavirus across the globe has dominated global attention. In Nigeria the Government at all levels is committed to the fight against its increasing spread. The presidential task force on containment of COVID-19 has from time to time brief Nigerians on the current trends of activities and efforts put in by the Government, organization and individuals to contain the spread of the Coronavirus. The spread of the virus has tremendously increased in the last two months (from Feb. to date 2020). The Nigeria Center for Disease Control (NCDC) has reported 12,801 confirmed cases as at 11:55pm, 8th of June 2020. Nigerian government is faced with hard choices about how to manage the virus. State Governors in Nigeria have already imposed border restrictions. Many are placing partial or blanket bans on public gatherings or insisting that citizen’s shelter at home. These are necessary but also costly measures. In Adamawa State, the governor imposed series of lockdown to contain the spread of the virus. Despite, the effort put by the government and other institutions such as the NCDC, there is a widespread notion by general public mostly in remote communities that Coronavirus is a lie and the perception that it is a foreign and rich persons’ sickness. Preventive measures such as social distancing, regular washing of hands or the use of hand sanitizers and other guidelines stipulated by the relevant authorities such as the NCDC are not properly adhered to. This project seeks to address “Knowledge and attitude on Coronavirus among IDPs and Host communities assessed” in 3 LGAs of Adamawa State (Yola North, Demsa and Girei). In line with SDG Goal 3, good health and well-being, Goal 4, Quality Education, Goal 5, Achieve gender equality and empower all women and girls AND Goal 16, Promote peaceful and inclusive societies for sustainable development, provide access to justice for all and build effective, accountable and inclusive institutions at all levels.

participating-org.narrative: Diocese of Yola, Justice and Peace Commission

receiver-org.narrative: Diocese of Yola, Justice and Peace Commission

title.narrative: Covid- 19 Intervention for the vulnerable Persons in Maiduguri Diocese

description.narrative: The COVID-19 pandemic is the defining global health crisis of our time. (it could be said to be the greatest challenge we have faced since World War Two). Since its emergence in China in December 2019, the virus has spread to 213 countries (including Nigeria) with the number of confirmed cases rising daily in Africa the Americas, and Europe. Countries are racing to slow the spread of the virus by testing and treating patients, carrying out contact tracing, limiting travel, quarantining citizens, and cancelling large gatherings such as sporting events, concerts, and schools. The wide increasing spread of Coronavirus across the globe has dominated global attention. In Nigeria the situation is not different as the Government at all level is committed to the fight against the increasing spread of COVID-19. The presidential task force on containment of COVID-19 has from time to time brief Nigerians on the current trends of activities and efforts put in by the Government, organization and individuals to contain the spread of the Coronavirus. The spread of the virus has tremendously increased in the last two months (from Feb. to date 2020). The Nigeria Center for Disease Control (NCDC) has reported 12,801 confirmed cases as at 11:55pm, 8th of June 2020. Nigerian government is faced with hard choices about how to manage the virus. State Governors in Nigeria have already imposed border restrictions. Many are placing partial or blanket bans on public gatherings or insisting that citizen’s shelter at home. These are necessary but also costly measures. In Maiduguri Diocese, there is a wide spread notion by general public mostly in remote communities that Coronavirus is a lie and the perception that, it is a foreign and rich persons’ sickness. Preventive measures such as social distancing, regular washing of hands or the use of hand sanitizers and other guidelines stipulated by the relevant authorities such as the NCDC are not properly adhered to. This Project is all about creating awareness on Covid-19 prevention and spread by enabling the vulnerable persons to have access to genuine knowledge on COVID19 and sanitary facilities to help curb its spread.

title.narrative: COVID-19 Emergency Intervention for vulnerable households in 2 states: FCT and Kano

description.narrative:
This proposed intervention intends to address water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH), food and nutritional insecurity as a result of COVID 19. Radio phone in program will be carried out to raise awareness among the populace. The COVID-19 pandemic is a health and human crisis pandemic threatening the food security and nutrition of millions of people in Nigeria. Hundreds of millions of people were already suffering from hunger and malnutrition before the virus hit and, unless immediate action is taken, we could witness acute food emergency in Nigeria. In the longer term, the combined effects of COVID-19 itself, as well as corresponding mitigation measures and the emerging global recession could, without large-scale coordinated action, disrupt the functioning of food systems. Such disruption can result in consequences for health and nutrition of a severity and scale unseen for more than half a century.
The intervention is also proposing to provide Preventive Protective Equipment (PPE) to one hospital in each of the target location of Abuja (FCT) and Kano state. The PPE will help the hospitals to be better protected and thus more disposed to support COVID patients. Shortage of PPE is one of the major challenge health care workers are faced in this pandemic. The Catholic church donated to the Nigerian government some centres across the country as isolation centres for the management of COVID. Two of these facilities will be benefit from these PPE.
The involvement of faith-based organizations in responding to health epidemics cannot be overemphasized. As revealed in a press statement by CAFOD; Christian and Muslim Leaders played, essential role in tackling the Ebola virus especially in dispelling rumours and promoting authentic health messages. With COVID-19 pandemic, in Nigeria, a lot of people still do not believe that the virus is real, thus resulting in neglect of government prevention messages.

title.narrative: Livelihood and recovery support for population affected by violent crisis in Southern Kaduna

description.narrative: Operational support for the project implemented in a consortium with Christian Aid. CAFOD is focusing in Kaura and Kauru LGAs of Kaduna state. The intervention will alleviate immediate suffering for the crisis affected people that will be targeted for this response while more resources are being mobilized from other partners and government stakeholders such as the State Emergency Management Agency (SEMA), National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA), Kaduna State Peace-Building Commission. The IDPs have migrated to a safe area from which they will move out and return to their homes as they still try to attend to their farms. This intervention will serve as mainly a lifesaving to stabilize them for the initial period before they feel safe to return as is the typical disposition of those in the middle region of Nigeria. Based on the assessment that has been conducted so far by Red Cross and local partner in the location, the needs are quite varied due to the nature by which households were displaced. The key sectors identified in the assessment findings were: Food, NFIs and WASH. More specifically, they included access to food and medication, NFIs, Blankets, hand-sanitisers, nose-masks, mattresses, toiletries, toilets, mosquito nets, sanitary items like sanitizers. There is also a need for risk communication intervention around sensitisation on the COVID-19 pandemic and protocols in disaster expecially as the targetted population are considered more vulnerable in the context and reality of the attacks and consequences. This needs-based, accountable and inclusive project will focus on the following key areas: 1. Cash grants to the 1,657 most vulnerable individuals to address food insecurity needs 2. NFI and WASH distributions to 15,000+ displaced individuals 3. Community sensitisation on EWS, Disaster Management and COVID-19 protocols to 15,000+ individuals

title.narrative: Livelihood and recovery support for population affected by violent crisis in Southern Kaduna

description.narrative: The project is implemented in a consortium with Christian Aid. CAFOD is focusing in Kaura and Kauru LGAs of Kaduna state. The intervention will alleviate immediate suffering for the crisis affected people that will be targeted for this response while more resources are being mobilized from other partners and government stakeholders such as the State Emergency Management Agency (SEMA), National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA), Kaduna State Peace-Building Commission. Start agency interventions would be able to meet the immediate needs of the affected population while any mobilised resources from the government would also support further recovery processes and or possible scale up. This intervention will serve as mainly a lifesaving to stabilize them for the initial period before they feel safe to return as is the typical disposition of those in the middle region of Nigeria. NFI and WASH distributions to 15,000+ displaced individuals 3. Community sensitisation on EWS, Disaster Management and COVID-19 protocols to 15,000+ individuals Note the WASH intervention will focus on the camps and host communities will also be strengthened to promote some basic guides and practices to forestall community transmission of the virus.

title.narrative: Supportn Recovery, Protectn and Livelihoods of the Marginalised, Displaced and Returnees in com BN St

description.narrative: The project will respond to WASH, Cash, Health, Protection and Disaster Risk Reduction (DRR) and NFIs. The response will reach beneficiaries experiencing health emergencies including Covid 19 and Yellow fever which are both WASH related emergencies to be addressed through an integrated risk communication and community engagements, local and mainstream approaches to WASH to maximize community participation and sustainability. Households and health facilities will be supported with Covid 19 WASH kits to strengthen infection prevention control (IPC) for Covid 19 to reduce community and facility transmission. WASH activities will mainstream yellow fever specifically with the provision of mosquito nets for households and facilities and also risk communication and community engagement activities including capacity building activities and Information Education and Communication (IEC) dissemination activities through local town criers for local reach and radio jingles for posters for wider reach. The project will train community volunteers who will track false information and myths at community levels and will urgently to address this false information using various channels such as door to door sensitisations, IEC materials and mass media engagements. Yet, there is high number of people dying from illness with symptoms like COVID. False and inaccurate information among young people is quickly being driven by - Low level of trust in authorities, particularly among IDPs due to lack of access to health services and information. - Traditional and beliefs and practices, such as traditional healing solutions, which can lead to increased exposure. - Fatalist attitudes closely linked to religious doctrines and practices. - Generic messaging that does not address gender, age, and geographically specific contexts. - Slow identification of misinformation, meaning that measures to combat it lose potency once it spreads within communities Water treatment kits will be provided.

title.narrative: Supporting Recovery, Protection and Livelihood of Marginalised, Displaced and Returnees on Com in BN St

description.narrative: Location: Otukpo: Asa, Akpegede, Ogobia, Okpoga and Adoka Emergency Response: WASH, CASH (UCT, Voucher/Token)PPE Project Duration: 2 Months 11/ 12/2020 to 09 /02 /2021 Project Total Budget: N 43,852,444.65 Direct Beneficiaries:900 Indirect Beneficiaries:4,500 persons @5 PPHH) Implementing Partners: CCFN through JDPC Otukpo Catholic Diocese Background The project will respond to WASH, Cash, Health, Protection and Disaster Risk Reduction (DRR) and NFIs. The response will reach beneficiaries experiencing health emergencies including Covid 19 and Yellow fever which are both WASH related emergencies to be addressed through an integrated risk communication and community engagements, local and mainstream approaches to WASH to maximize community participation and sustainability. Households and health facilities will be supported with Covid 19 WASH kits to strengthen infection prevention control (IPC) for Covid 19 to reduce community and facility transmission. WASH activities will mainstream yellow fever specifically with the provision of mosquito nets for households and facilities and also risk communication and community engagement activities including capacity building activities and Information Education and Communication (IEC) dissemination activities through local town criers for local reach and radio jingles for posters for wider reach. The project will train community volunteers who will track false information and myths at community levels and will urgently to address this false information using various channels such as door to door sensitisations, IEC materials and mass media engagements. Yet, there is high number of people dying from illness with symptoms like COVID. False and inaccurate information among young people is quickly being driven by - Low level of trust in authorities, particularly among IDPs due to lack of access to health services and information. - Traditional and beliefs and practices, such as traditional healing solutions, which can increase.

title.narrative: Contributing to the reduction of violence, sexual exploitation and discrimination against HIV in León

description.narrative:
This project consists of developing accompaniment processes with adolescents in situations of vulnerability to sexual violence and sexual exploitation, applying the Mary Barreda Association (MB) working method.
In this process MB works on the reduction of risk factors and the increase of protective factors, to achieve emotional recovery, the strengthening of family ties, social and family reintegration. The approach is carried out in a differentiated way: those who are in a situation of sexual exploitation and those at risk, so that they do not reach the situation, from the preventive approach, both with individual and group attention, the work with families being one of the main strategies, to develop a facilitating context that positively favours their processes.
The intervention also includes women victims of violence and in a situation of prostitution: empowerment processes, self-help groups and psycho-legal accompaniment are carried out so that they can report and demand justice before the appropriate authorities.
MB wants the population to recognise that violence in all its expressions should not be seen as natural or inevitable: trafficking, sexual exploitation, HIV, criminal acts that violates the rights of children, adolescents and adult women, must be reported to the corresponding bodies guaranteeing their protection. This is done through campaigns: written, radio, television, distribution of communication and dissemination materials, information fairs, mass awareness activities, mobile cinemas, street theater, radio, television, social networks, website, promotion and testing of HIV, workshops, meetings.
To achieve compliance with this project, inter-institutional and inter sector coordination and bilateral spaces are carried out, as well as planning; monitoring; six months, year and intermediate evaluations.
Due to COVID-19 impact, instead of a new 3 year project with a new group of teenagers, this project is extended with a year 4 to work with the same teenagers to ensure protective factors development for their disengagement from sexual exploitation.

title.narrative: Strengthening the Healthy Communities Network to improve the population's access to health services

description.narrative: Since the beginning of the COVID - 19 pandemic, clinics and dispensaries have implemented measures to prevent infection and to protect staff, their families and patients who come for medical assistance using poor materials they were able to obtain. Through this project, educational and/or information materials will be developed to be placed in at least the 3 most visible locations in each dispensary and clinic. The dispensaries or nurses, as well as the doctors, will play a key role in orienting the patients, their companions on the protocol for the prevention of COVID-19 from the moment they enter the premises, as well as within the premises to avoid outbreaks. To facilitate increased access of 136,200 vulnerable people in 30 municipalities to the health services provided by the COMSALUD Network in conditions of safety and human warmth, through the reactivation of the medical care provided by the Network's community clinics and the implementation of 12 new Social Medicine shops (VSM)

participating-org.narrative: Instituto de Acción Social Juan XXIII

receiver-org.narrative: Instituto de Acción Social Juan XXIII

title.narrative: Supporting Caritas-development-Niger in the Covid-19 response

description.narrative:
Niger registered its first case of Covid-19 on 19 March 2020 and since then the number of cases has only increased and as of April 14, 2019, 570 cases have been declared positive for covid-19 of which 90 patients were cured and 14 died. This situation is most worrying because of the pre-existing factors that increase the vulnerability of the population to the pandemic and will make it very difficult for the Government to carry out its response activities to Covid-19. Among these factors are the following: Epidemic meningitis during this dry season, voluntary deprivation of food during Ramadan, risk of propagation of Covid-19 because of Transhumant movements, Agricultural lean season and Water shortage throughout the country
In this situation, the involvement of everyone remains the only way to overcome this epidemic.
This project will therefore support our partner Cadev Niger in its planned activities and its support to the initiatives taken by the government to respond to this epidemic. In the name of the Caritas Country Forum, CADEV will intervene in the activities of sensitization of the population, training of health workers on topics related to the prevention and management of nosocomial diseases in general and Covid-19 in particular, supply of personal protective equipment and other medical consumables, supply of water, hygiene and sanitation (WASH) in the hospital environment, mainly in the 36 health facilities operated by the Catholic Church.
The project will be financed by all the organizations of the Caritas Country Forum (Niger).

title.narrative: Supporting Caritas-development-Niger in the Covid-19 response

description.narrative:
With the progressive increase of Covid-19 cases since the first case was recorded on 29 March 2020 in Niger, the situation is becoming increasingly worrying because Niger is one of the countries with the weakest health system to cope with this pandemic. In addition to this, there are other factors that make the situation more and more worrying and increase the vulnerability of the population in the face of this pandemic and make the response very complex and the pandemic difficult to manage. Among these factors we can mention: difficult access to water due to the dry season, transhumance movements that favour the spread of the pandemic, the seasonal meningitis that Niger often experiences during this period, the agricultural lean season which increases food insecurity and the low level of knowledge on prevention measures of the population. As of 17 April 2020 Niger has registered a total of 627 confirmed cases of Covid-19 of which 110 are warned and 18 are died. In order to support the efforts and initiatives of prevention and response put in place by the government, the intervention of all actors is very important to face this worrying public health problem. It is in this logic that this project proposal is submitted to enable CADEV-Niger to contribute to the activities planned by the Covid-19 response and coordination committee set up by the government of Niger.
In line with the goals of our Country Strategy Paper which mandates CAFOD to intervene in emergency situations in support of our partner depending on the availability of resources, this project therefore aims to support our long-term partner CADEV-Niger which has agreed to represent the Caritas country forum in the response to Covid-19.
This project will focus mainly on activities to sensitize the population on measures to prevent the spread of Covid-19 from the 36 health areas where the 36 health centres run by the Catholic Church are located. All activities are planned and will be implemented according to the national response plan.

title.narrative: Support to vulnerable households affected by floods in Niger 2020

description.narrative:
Niger is facing a current context of climate change in the Sahelian region. Its annual rainfall, between 100 and 800 mm, is characterized by significant interannual and spatial variability with consequent droughts and/or floods. These harsh climatic conditions affect agro-silvo-pastoral production and the socio-economic conditions of the populations. Floods are observed during the rainy period between June and September of almost every year. Some of the factors that contribute to these floods are the following: - pressure urban demographic growth: migration of the rural poor to the cities, fleeing the misery of their land. - Uncontrolled occupation of areas potentially exposed to flood risks, - Failure of the city's sewerage network, - changes in land use resulting in altered surface conditions and increased runoff, etc.
As of October 1, 549,049 people have been affected by the floods following the heavy rainfall recorded since July in the eight regions of the country, according to estimates by the Ministry of Humanitarian Action and Disaster Management. This exceeds the Flood Contingency Plan's forecast of 250,000 people likely to be affected by floods this year when heavy rainfall is expected, according to the national meteorological services. To date, 69 people have died. The balance sheet also shows more than 39,000 houses damaged ; 67 classrooms, 36 mosques and one health facility have collapsed, more than 15,000 hectares of farmland destroyed destroyed and more than more than 15,000 head of cattle killed. This project therefore aims to provide food and non-food items to vulnerable households affected by these floods. Covid-19 fighting activities will also be implemented in the framework of this project to limit the spread of the virus between the affected populations.

title.narrative: Support to people living with disabilities impacted by the Covid-19 pandemic in Niger

description.narrative:
Having registered its first case on March 29, 2020, Niger has accumulated by January 30, 2021, 4433 positive cases out of 72624 tests performed. Out of the 4433 positive cases, 3583 cases have been declared cured, 153 people have died and 697 active cases are being treated. This pandemic context aggravates an already unstable and poor health situation characterised by persistent seasonal epidemics (meningitis, measles), a high mortality rate (Maternal mortality rate: 509 per 100,000 live births, Deaths under five: 85 per 1,000 live births) against the backdrop of a very weak health system and factors that increase the vulnerability of the population or facilitate the spread of the virus (drought, food insecurity, transhumance, difficulty of access to water). The negative impact of this pandemic is not only health-related, but also economic, especially in a country where human development indicators are very low, making Niger one of the poorest countries in the world, chronically affecting more than a quarter of the population (26.8%). This impact is much more pronounced among the disabled population than among the rest of the population. People with disabilities are particularly disadvantaged by the socio-economic consequences of COVID-19 and the measures taken to control the pandemic. The risk of contracting COVID-19 is higher among people with disabilities and the risk of medical complications and death related to COVID-19 is higher among people with disabilities. With an estimated population of 22.8 million, Niger is one of the countries with one of the highest natural population growth rates in the world (3.9% per year)1 and the disabled population is estimated at 4.2% (2.11% women and 2.06% men) .
This project therefore aims to support people with disabilities to reduce the considerable economic and health impact that this pandemic has on their daily lives by providing them with food to meet their immediate needs but also by supporting their income-generating activities and ensuring the strengthening of their capacities or by accompanying them in learning the profession in order to strengthen their long-term resilience. This project will support people with disabilities to become stakeholders in the prevention of Covid-19 by raising their awareness of the barriers against Covid-19, by training and supporting women with disabilities in the sewing of masks in line with government recommendations. Hand washing kits adapted to people with disabilities as well as other pandemic prevention equipment and products will be distributed to the beneficiaries (disinfectant gels).

title.narrative: Food and hygiene distributions for vulnerable families affected by COVID19

description.narrative: Due to the shutdown in the West Bank because of COVID-19 thousands of day labourers and other low-paid workers are unable to earn, and their families are suffering disproportionately as they have no savings, so have no money to buy food and maintain power and water. They also have no money for hygiene equipment to protect themselves and prevent spread of the virus. Coping strategies such as support from family, churches and mosques have already been exchausted. Caritas Jerusalem is planning to organise distributions of food and hygiene equipment over the next 2 months for 500 vulnerable families.

title.narrative: Support to Caritas Jerusalem COVID-19 health care response in Gaza

description.narrative:
There was an unprecedented surge in COVID-19 in the Gaza Strip in November and early December; active cases have doubled in the oPt overall and tripled in Gaza. The delivery of essential routine health services continues to be affected by the pandemic. The health authorities in Gaza announced the closure of all public outpatient clinics and the temporary suspension of elective surgeries for two weeks on November 24, while maintaining urgent and life-saving surgeries only.
Therefore, preventive measures like social distancing, hygiene practices, hand hygiene, and strengthening the immune systems of vulnerable people, many of whom are food insecure are of paramount importance.
This project will provide medical care in the homes of people who have tested positive for Covid-19 and/or people who need emergency primary heath care. It will also provide nutritional supplements to help improve the immune systems of people at risk in poor, over-crowded and multi-generational homes. The project, coordinated by the Ministry of Health in collaboration with Caritas Jerusalem, is designed to prevent spread of the virus and relieve pressure on the under-resourced and overcrowded public hospitals. The five medical teams will visit homes and assess the possibility of keeping the infected isolated in their own homes. If their houses are not suited for isolation, Caritas Jerusalem will refer to MoH isolation centres. Caritas Jerusalem will also provide non-COVID-19 related primary health care e.g. dressing changes, provision of medication as necessary.
In addition, Caritas will give hygiene kits in order to keep the homes virus free as much as possible as well as distributing flyers to raise awareness and the Caritas Jerusalem hotline number for additional enquiries.

title.narrative: Children and teenagers, protagonists in promoting their rights in districts of northern Lima

description.narrative: This new project aims to continue with the progress made during the previous project PER298, whilst incorporating a new element, ie the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the lives of children and teenagers, and a focus on strengthening capacities of parent helpers. This project seeks to strengthen the organisational capacity of the communities of Lomas de Carabayllo, in favour of the rights of children and teenagers, ensuring they have a leading role in promoting, monitoring and advocating for the rights of children and teenagers, together with community leaders, local government and others government entities. The project will focus primarily on four rights: education, protection, participation and a healthy environment. Skills of communities and children's organisations will be strengthened to monitor and prevent situations that violate the rights of children and teenagers, particularly in the pandemic and post-pandemic context where the lives of children and teenagers have been dramatically impacted. The response capacity of local government and other government entities will also be strengthened to meet demands, guarantee rights and prevent violations. In Year 1, case management models for support with domestic violence will be developed; in Year 1 a 10-month programme of support for the ollas comunes will also be incorporated.

title.narrative: Habitat and community risk management and climate change in Lomas de Carabayllo

description.narrative: This project is a continuation of PER294. Building on the achievements of PER294, CIDAP will continue to strengthen the skills of women, men and young people in Lomas de Carabayllo, targeting 9 urban settlements. CIDAP’s work will focus on DRR, including the food crisis, on climate change adaptation, youth environmental leadership and the conservation of Lomas de la Primavera in the context of the coronavirus pandemic, with an emphasis on food security. In addition, in the first year of the project, CIDAP will support environmental human rights defenders, who are threatened due to land invaders and land traffickers, developing a protocol for their support and documenting cases, to be used to advocate for their protection, and will provide some support to the 'ollas comunes' which have been established in solidarity 12 urban settlements.

participating-org.narrative: Centro de Investigación, Documentación y Asesoría Poblacional - CIDAP

receiver-org.narrative: Centro de Investigación, Documentación y Asesoría Poblacional - CIDAP
Centro de Investigación, Documentación y Asesoría Poblacional - CIDAP

title.narrative: Synodal route: participation and empowerment of indigenous women, Puerto Maldonado, Pucallpa, Lima

description.narrative: During the synodal process and in the context of Covid-19, the fragile participation of indigenous women in communal spaces has become evident due to machista and discriminatory practices that have placed them in a secondary role with little space to express their opinions, participate and lead, despite the fact that women's participation is of utmost importance for the development, cultural revitalisation and future of their communities. The project builds on projects PER309 and PER311, and aims to strengthen the participation of indigenous Amazonian women from the Vicariates of Puerto Maldonado, Pucallpa and the Shipiba community of Cantagallo, an indigenous population living in Lima, to enable their voices to be heard and to encourage the Amazonian Church to take on board the leading role of indigenous women from a synodal perspective. The project aims to support, through training and accompaniment, the creation of new female leaders, as well as to strengthen existing female leaders. This will enable them to defend their rights as women and representatives of indigenous peoples. It also aims to generate spaces for coordination n and communication between indigenous women artists of the Amazonian peoples through meetings that allow for the creation of an artistic exhibition, which will be a valuable advocacy tool.

participating-org.narrative: Centro Amazónico de Antropología y Aplicación Práctica

receiver-org.narrative: Centro Amazónico de Antropología y Aplicación Práctica

title.narrative: COVID-19 Emergency Response in El Fasher, and CoVERED North Darfur

description.narrative: While COVID-19 is principally a public health emergency, the pandemic has engendered significant socio-economic impact on the people of Sudan. Pre-COVID-19 Sudan already faced a highly complex socio-economic and political environment. This includes new and protracted displacement of large parts of the population, regional insecurity, inflation and high levels of chronic malnutrition and food insecurity. The situation is likely to be worsened by the COVID-19 pandemic. There are fears that COVID-19 would likely further increase the risk of mortality for those populations whose health status is already compromised by acute malnutrition. The project will provide food security and livelihoods support to at least 250 most vulnerable households (approximately 1500 people) drawn from the 16 villages where CAFOD and SAG are undertaking RISING II project activities. The project will assist households to transition through the lean season by providing them with food basket vouchers, restocking vouchers; and address critical WASH facilities/materials and information on COVID-19 infection and prevention. Specific objectives: At least 250 most vulnerable HHs in El Fasher rural have their basic emergency food and livelihood needs met. At least 1500 vulnerable and at-risk women, men, boys and girls in El Fasher rural adopt preventative behaviours to protect themselves and others from COVID-19 Outputs. 1.100 HHs provided with vouchers for restocking (each household to receive vouchers worth one goat/sheep) 2.250 HHs provided for two months with food vouchers (SDG 4500 per month) 3.16 Hand Washing Facilities (HWF) installed in 16 villages 4.32 awareness campaigns undertaken in the 16 villages on COVID-19 infection prevention and control. 5. 3200 IEC materials on COVID-19 infection prevention and control produced and distributed to during the awareness campaigns. The other funding stream which is 2nd approval ae from CoVERED funds under FFP and linked to Type 2 Project SDN116

title.narrative: Operational costs for COVID-19 Economic Recovery and Emergency Delivery (CovERED) in North Darfur

description.narrative: While COVID-19 is principally a public health emergency, the pandemic will have a significant socio-economic impact on the people of Sudan. Modelling by the Centre for Disease Dynamics, Economics and Policy estimates that between 40,000 to 60,000 people will develop a severe infection as a result of COVID-19 in Sudan with much dependent on the movement restriction approaches adopted by the Government. Pre-COVID-19, Sudan already faced a highly complex socio-political environment. This includes new and protracted displacement of large parts of the population, regional insecurity and high levels of chronic malnutrition and food insecurity nationwide. CAFOD is participating in consortium led by CRS to respond to the COVID-19 in ND with support of funds from FFP The project Goal is: Vulnerable urban communities in Darfur survive with dignity, restore their lives and communities in the face of COVID-19 Strategic Objectives: 1.Strategic Objective 1: Mitigate health impacts of COVID-19 Intermediate Result 1.1: Communities in Darfur adopt preventative behaviors to protect themselves and others from COVID-19 2.Strategic Objective 2: COVID-19 affected households have met their basic food and hygiene needs. Intermediate Result 2.1: People living in urban areas of Darfur meet their food and other essential needs throughout the lean season Cross-cutting priorities: Safe and dignified programming approaches: will ensure equitable access, especially for the most vulnerable and at-risk groups; accountability to the people we serve; support of self-protection capacities; and Do No Harm principles. Partnership with local and national actors: will leverage vast, long-standing relationships with government institutions, local organizations and civil society networks to heighten reach and scale.

title.narrative: Food Security and Livelihoods assistance to vulnerable host communities in El Salam locality, White

description.narrative: The overall objective of the project is to provide basic lifesaving Food Security and Livelihoods (FSL) support to at least 15,000 people (about 3,000 HHs) in four villages/communities (El Radis 1, El Radis 2, Jouri and Um Sangor) in El Salam locality, White Nile State. Affected population to be targeted by the project will be vulnerable host communities (HCs) members, with specific focus on Female Headed Households (FHH), People With Disability (PWD), families with members who are elderly, children under five and families worst affected by COVID-19 crisis. Key considerations will be made to ensure specific safety, privacy and security needs of women, girls, men, boys and people with special needs are addressed during delivery of project activities. Project activities will specifically seek to provide and enable vulnerable HCs members access lifesaving FSL support, which will include provision of agricultural inputs (winter season seeds and tools through vouchers and DiNER Fairs) and services (training, and field extension services); provision of quality veterinary (vaccination and treatment) and extension services (training, and field extension services); provision of emergency livelihoods (restocking, fishing) start up packages (through vouchers) and activities (establishment of Saving and Internal Lending Committees - SILCs - trainings and networking) and; cash for work (digging of drainage tunnels and soil silos in preparation of the rainy seasons). Community Pest Scouts (CPS) will be trained on identifications of nymphs, fall army worms and other common crop pests and diseases to strengthen community early warning systems and preparedness. The CPSs will also support on alerts such as floods during the agricultural season. The project will integrate messages on COVID-19 and cholera/AWD (in view of the on-coming rains starting from July/August) infection, prevention and control during community awareness sessions and field extension services.

title.narrative: Food Security and Livelihood (FSL) support for vulnerable households in El Fasher, North Darfur

description.narrative:
The will project will support rural communities who have been largely affected by the deteriorating economic situation resulting in rapid price increases compounded by the negative and prolonged effects of the Covid-19 in North Darfur . Thus the project will target vulnerable men, women, boys , girls and the elderly who are at risk of starvation and malnutrition as a result of heightening food insecurity and families who have lost their income ( employment ) due to the Coivd-19 pandemic . The project will seek to address immediate needs arising from the impact of COVID-19 and the deteriorating economic situation which is causing unprecedented price increases putting vulnerable house at risk.
Project specific objectives are: 1.To enable vulnerable households in El Fashir rural to recover from the Covid-19 and economic shocks through small livestock support (goats and sheep), training and animal vaccination 2.To improve the nutritional status of vulnerable households in El Fashir rural bu supporting them with essential vegetable seeds, tools to establish home gardens and provision of training on nutrition sensitive agriculture.
The following are the project outputs. 1.640 HHs provided with vouchers for restocking (each household to receive vouchers worth one goat/sheep) 2.1600 individuals trained on small livestock management (sheep and goats) 3.Livestock vaccination conducted for 3200 (goats and sheep) 4.1600 individuals trained on veld and pasture management 5.1600 HHs provided with vegetable seeds and tools through market fairs (PLWs, LM and Care Group members) 6.1600 individuals trained on organic manure/compost making for home gardening. 7. 1600 individuals trained on nutrition sensitive agriculture ( PLW, LM and Care Group members)
Project project target beneficiaries/HHs will be drawn from RISING II project sites (16 target villages) in El Fasher locality, North Darfur State.

title.narrative: COVID-19: Building Resilience through WASH, Sustainable Agriculture and Food and Income Security

description.narrative:
Due to the global outbreak of COVID-19 and with cases already reported in Sierra Leone, this grant was re-purposed in order to respond to the growing needs of the local community and to prevent any community transmission to the Health Clinic operated by the Handmaid Sisters. The funds will be used to procure hygiene promotion materials (buckets, soap, cleaning liquids among others) for both the clinic and surrounding communities and provide the necessary protective equipment for clinic staff (face masks, rubber boots, thermometers, goggles, hand gloves etc).
CAFOD will also support the Handmaid Sisters to complete the construction of hand-dug wells in order to support the WASH needs of local communities; ensuring that proper prevention methods can continue through access to clean water for hand-washing. Recognizing the economic impact that lock-downs and travel restrictions will have on an already fragile economy, this project will also work to support local communities through agricultural training on post harvest losses, and provide inputs in the form of tools, seeds, small ruminants and goats. The Handmaid Sisters will also seek to improve the economic resilience of women and vulnerable individuals through a micro-loan scheme.

participating-org.narrative: The Sisters of the Congregation of the Handmaids of the Holy Child Jesus
