title.narrative: COVID-19: Cash Transfer Programme

description.narrative:
The Diocese of Kenema is located along the Liberian border and is comprised of some of the most remote and rural communities in Sierra Leone. Poor infrastructure, especially during the rainy season, can often limit the movement of goods and services within these communities; negatively impacting upon their economic livelihoods. As a result, there is a need to support these vulnerable individuals with cash transfers through mobile money, allowing them to determine what goods or services best address their current needs in the midst of this outbreak. Given the characteristics of the target group, they are extremely susceptible to economic shocks and many are already suffering from income insecurity, worsened by the outbreak. A large proportion of these populations either depend on subsistence farming for their livelihoods, or petty trading especially for the vulnerable women.
With the outbreak of COVID-19, a series of regulations have been imposed by the Government to control the spread of the virus across the Country. Some of these regulations like the inter-district lockdowns, periodic mandatory 3-day lockdowns, social distancing measures and night curfews, limit the movement of people and hampers their economic activities. This has resulted in further worsening of the vulnerability status of the already impoverished populations. The proposed action will provide the target groups with cash transfers through a mobile service provider for three months, to ensure that their basic needs can still be met. The project will also engage one volunteer per chiefdom, to assist in both spreading messaging about the importance of still seeking medical attention, for pregnant mothers and teenagers, as well as lactating mothers, PWDs and the elderly, and also encourage the participating beneficiaries to use the funds judiciously in order to ensure that their families are catered for at the end of the day.

title.narrative: Emergency Response to the COVID-19 Epidemic in Western Bahr el Ghazal

description.narrative:
On April 5th 2020, South Sudan confirmed its first COVID-19 case within its borders. The announcement did not come as a surprise for the humanitarian community as the country was one of the last ones in Africa to not report any cases despite the fact that the number of cases at its borders has been consistently increasing over the last few weeks. Although the announcement of an additional case in South Sudan on April 7th cannot be interpreted as a sign of large spread of the disease, it surely isn’t a positive indicator for the South Sudanese population. Indeed, if the two confirmed cases are both employees of the same international organisation in Juba, official sources declared they did not have contact between each other thus indicating there are other cases undetected. More importantly, uncertainty remains high on the actual caseload of contaminated individuals as only very few number of tests, around thirty, have been conducted since the beginning of the crisis, underlying the lack of capacity of the health sector to face such outbreak.
Should COVID-19 spread across the country, as it will unfortunately most likely be the case, there is no doubt that the health system will not be able to respond effectively as the health facilities coverage is particularly weak due to inadequate human resources, funding and essential commodities. As detailed in the START FUND alert raised on April 6th, only approximately 1,000 health facilities providing healthcare services are functional while only two ventilators are available in the whole country (although essential equipment in case of respiratory complications due to COVID-19). As South Sudan is already facing a worrying humanitarian situation with almost half of all counties having a convergence of high needs related to food insecurity, protection, and water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH), thorough preparedness is an essential mean to limit the epidemic spread and impact.

title.narrative: COVID – 19 Preparedness and Emergency Response

description.narrative: DMI is implementing the CGF funded Self – Reliance and sustainability of peace in conflict affected areas of Aguok South and North in Gogrial (SSD203). Although Gogrial has not yet recorded cases of COVID-19 infections, as a preventive mechanism and to prepare the communities before infections spread, we propose to undertake emergency preparedness and response to build community awareness among key stakeholders, SDMIC staff team, project beneficiaries through reaching activity locations, public places and target families through outreach sanitization in five rural communities. We would use the ongoing project intervention platforms such as peace and reconciliation communities, women self-help groups, parents and teachers’ associations and school peace clubs in sensitizing and reaching the larger community on COVID 19. Volunteers, SDMIC staff team, women self-help groups leaders and peace and reconciliation committee leaders would make home visits (during home visit, volunteers and leaders would adhere to social distancing) and orient families about the preventive measures and personal hygiene. Illiteracy rates are high particularly among women which keeps a large percentage of the community people from important information about the outbreak of the COVID 19 that comes through the regular media and other forms of modern (online) communication. Diverse public awareness activities will focus on distributing pamphlets, displaying banners, public awareness through megaphone, placing hygiene and sanitation kits in public places like markets, clinics, PRC meeting center, Self Help Group meeting centers, peace dialogues points. Home visit and awareness-raising are important for direct messaging in local language since there is high levels of illiteracy. Radio messages in local languages will also be used to provide information on social distancing, hand washing and emphasis on staying at home. The messaging will also be used to communicate accurate information which has been cleared by UNICEF, WHO and Ministry of Health. This will counter fake information which is being circulated in various platforms such as social media platforms. The preparedness response would also prevent stigmatization of people perceived to be coming from the virus prone locations.

participating-org.narrative: Society Of Daughters of Mary Immaculate

receiver-org.narrative: Society Of Daughters of Mary Immaculate

title.narrative: Operational support for Peacebuilding opportunities during times of COVID-19.

description.narrative: This project will adopt the POF (Peacebuilding opportunities fund) project to COVID 19 through CAFOD, CRN, SSBS-HD through Bakhita Radio station in Juba with repeat of talk shows done in other Diocesan Radios in South Sudan. The project will focus on peacebuilding, identifying opportunities for peacebuilding, social adjustments in cultural and social practices and COVID-19 health matters. Discussions will also focus on GBV through engagement of community leaders, opinion leaders and general citizens through educative messaging, interviews with peacebuilding, health and gender programming experts. There will be interactive discussions on various themes including peace building, GBV and COVID-19 infection risk reduction measures to ensure that accurate information is available to affected populations in an accessible and culturally appropriate manner. There will be sessions for radio talk shows, question and answer sessions with peace building, health and gender experts, vox pops, radio dramas, songs and jingles to pass on information and messages.

title.narrative: Operational support for creating public awareness on Corona Virus (COVID 19) South Sudan

description.narrative: This project will work through its established and well-networked radio stations across 7 dioceses to raise awareness amongst the general public on COVID-19 to prevent and mitigate the pandemic. Through messaging it will encourage the public to adopt COVID-19 risk reduction practices. SSCBS Health Department which will provide technical support in the creation of accurate content which will be beamed to the public. The SSCBS coordinates with WHO and MoH and is up to date with developments and information on the Covid-19. CRN in collaboration with The SSCBS Health Department will regularly coordinate radio talk shows across CRNs supported radio stations hosting teams of experts from the Ministry of Health, WHO and others. SSCBS will play a key role in collaborating with the Government, Ministry of Health, WHO and other relevant institutions to get updated information on COVID-19. The SSCBS health department who have technical experts will train Journalists on COVID-19 on how to collect and pass accurate information to the public.

title.narrative: Support to SSCBS and facilitation of allowances to Regional Health Coordinators

description.narrative: This support will be focused on operational facilitation of South Sudan Catholic Bishop Secretariat Health coordinator in coordination of awareness raising on COVID-19 Response, prevention in relation to Peace building, women empowerment and social aspects and perceptions. the project will also facilitate allowances for Regional health coordinators who actively participate in live Radio shows in 7 Catholic Diocesan Radios in south Sudan

title.narrative: Covid19 response in Juba, South Sudan

description.narrative: This project is raised to respond to COVID19 in Juba, South Sudan. South Sudan’s first confirmed case of COVID-19 was on 5 April 2020, by 24 July 2020 cases had surged to 2,258 with 45 deaths. Cases are reported from 16 out of 78 counties, with Juba, being most affected. Insufficient testing limits the ability to accurately assess the scope of the pandemic. COVID-19 infections are expected to increase significantly and more significantly impact urban poor and IDP camp residents due to factors including high density living conditions (preventing social distancing and making isolation difficult), levels of risk awareness and adoption of prevention and control practices are low, access to WaSH and health care facilities are low and prevalence of existing health conditions (including malaria, diarrhoea), food insecurity and malnutrition is high, particularly at this time of year. The elderly, people with disabilities and women carers (higher exposure risk) are particularly vulnerable, with women more likely to be health workers, community mobilisers or IDPs. CAFOD will implement the project with its local implementing partner Titi Foundation. The project will be implemented in Juba city and strive to deliver safe, accessible, and dignified COVID-19 risk communications, protection services, and food security, as well as foster and enable good hygiene, and sanitation practices for the most vulnerable. The overall programme design and implementation will be guided and underpinned by accountability, protection mainstreaming, inclusive and conflict sensitive approaches. This response plan is designed in line with the revised Humanitarian Response Plan (HRP) of South Sudan, developed taking COVID-19 risk into account.

title.narrative: To save lives and reduce sufferings of flood affected individuals through provision of dignified, ti

description.narrative: This project is to respond to floods affected people in Mangala Payam of Juba County Central Equatoria State. Since July 2020, an estimated 1,034,000 people have been affected by floods and of those people affected, some 481,000 were estimated to have been displaced from their homes by the floods. People were affected in locations across Unity, Upper Nile, Warrap, Western Equatoria, Central Equatoria and Northern Bahr-el-Ghazal States. The urgent survival needs identified by IRNA include food and livelihood support, emergency shelter and non-food items (ES/NFI), and WASH, health, and protection services. Flood response activities are considerably constrained by persistent heavy rains, infrastructure damage and reduced physical accessibility (e.g., impassable roads, flooded airstrips), insecurity and limited resources. Core WaSH Pipeline has been reported depleted by IOM due to COVID 19. This caused difficulty to address urgent needs of flood affected people. The South Sudan Humanitarian Response Plan is funded at some 50 per cent of the total ask of US$1.9 billion, as of 18 November 2020. The total requirement for the current response was estimated at $81.9 million. More than $16 million has been mobilized from ECHO, DFID, and USAID in response to the floods and displacement.

title.narrative: Financial support for the position of General Secretary and Finance officer.

description.narrative: The South Sudan Council of Churches (SSCC) has been implementing Action Plan for peace (APP) since the the development of APP through statement of intent which developed delivery of 4 programme outcome relating to advocacy, neutral forum, reconciliation, and institutional development. Through this church based nation wide and multi-stake engagement action, the SSCC envisage the realization of a peaceful resolution of conflicts and restoration of peace in South Sudan. The first phase of the the APP 2016-2017 has ended and SSCC is now implementing a new phase 2018-2021 through annual funding from all its partners including CTP, and Christian Aid, and PAX, all church Aid, working collaboratively under the structure core Group whose work is to mobile funding and provide technical support to SSCC in the implementation of APP South Sudan like many other countries is constrained unprecedentedly by social and economic systems breakdown because of COVID-19. Not only is the COVID-19. Not only is the COVID-19 pandemic a threat to physical health and the economy. it has a well affected funding for partners and SSCC is not an exception. Given the peace agreement signed is seemly taking shape continue the SSCC would like to continue scaling up its operation in Equatorial and Greater Upper Nile Regions. The council under capacity strengthening outcomes would like to request CTP to support the General Secretary and Finance officer (Accountant) in the secretariat. The position of the General Secretary existed before when the Action Plan for peace (APP) was launched and it manages all the functions in the SSCC Secretariat. This position is covered solely supported by SSCC through its assets which is also badly affected by the economic setback leaving all percentages for support of SSCC secretariat whose financial support tremendously reduced due to reduction in its retained income. The stability in all regions is paying the way for full implementation of APP activities in all the location, SSCC has also already recruited a Finance officer who is based at the head office. The finance officer is responsible for managing all financial records of the regions including partners and donor funds for implementation of activities in the regions and gives support to the finance department at the head office. The finance officer will report directly to finance manager at SSCC headquarters and shall administration have supervised by regional coordinator equatorial region.

Hardware and installation chargers 2. internet subscription for 12 months 3. transport cost 4. maintenance 5. Accommodation for technicians

title.narrative: Improve living standards and community environment to the vulnerable families and groups in Homs

description.narrative: Homs is the third largest city after Damascus and Aleppo in terms of population. Prior to the crisis, around 1.8 million people lived in Homs (2011). Current figures indicate that the total population is only around 1.42 mil., 360,000 of whom are IDPs from different parts of the country. The city of Homs was declared a safe city in May 2018 after Al-Waar area returned to to the GoS control in the Northwest region. Despite the stable security situation, humanitarian needs are increasing with the increasing number of returnees as well as the IDPs who are moving to the governorate from hotspots, especially from Al-Rukban camp. COVID-19 crisis led to massive economic losses in Syria and it has exacerbated pre-existing high level of poverty in Syria generally and in Homs particularly after 9 years of war. In a needs assessment conducted prior to the design of the project, Caritas Homs identified the following priority needs: 1. Survival needs among the most vulnerable 2. Protection needs of civilians 3. Livelihood and essential basic services Therefore, the project will include multipurpose cash to cover basic living needs (food security, shelter and NFIs and Medication), protection activities such as literacy courses, social cohesion activities with youth, psychosocial support to elderly people, income generating activities through trainings, cash grants and toolkit distributions. The project will take place in Homs city and Al-Qusayr in rural Homs.

title.narrative: Uganda COVID19 Response Project

description.narrative:
The purpose of this project is to enable the Uganda Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace to; - Contribute to local and national efforts to mitigate further spread and impact of COVID19 by implementing early action and anticipatory activities (awareness raising, advocacy, prepositioning and advocacy). - Support and respond to needs arising from COVID19 pandemic in Uganda and address existing gaps. - Provide assistance to vulnerable groups that were not previously identified or covered by existing responses.
The overall objective of the project is to save lives and alleviate suffering by delivering coordinated preventive and precautionary messages, protection and assistance to people from marginalised, hard to reach communities and informal settlements, displaced, the elderly, women and children majority of whom rely on Church support.
Outcome 1: Improved community and public awareness on health-promoting behaviours and to combat misinformation.
Activity 1.1. Facilitate Uganda Catholic Bishops to conduct educative and awareness programs, using selected Radio and TV Stations, on prevention, precautionary messages and mitigation response to communities on COVID 19.
Activity 1.2 Support Catholic Bishops to produce government guidelines on COVID19 and to disseminate to all 19 Catholic Dioceses of Uganda.
Activity 1.3 Support Catholic Bishops to produce and disseminate guidelines on preventive mechanisms against COVID19.

participating-org.narrative: Uganda Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace

receiver-org.narrative: Uganda Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace

title.narrative: Humanitarian Assistance and Protection for Families Affected by the Protracted Crisis in Venezuela

description.narrative:
This project will support the CI Emergency Appeal 16/2020 for Venezuela. The EA will provide continuity to the projects implemented by Caritas Venezuela since 2015 which aimed at improving access to health and food for the most vulnerable population. The EA was launched in 2020 and set to last 36 months (2020-2023) to improve the response to the health and nutrition-related needs of the most vulnerable communities, now aggravated by the additional needs created by COVID-19.
Caritas Venezuela proposed a range of complementary interventions, involving diocesan and parish Caritas agencies, with two interconnected strategic axes: food security, nutrition, wash, cash and health. These activities include the provision of Personal Protection Equipment (PPE) kits, hygiene, nutritional supplements for children under 59 months, pregnant and lactating women, as well as food for daily consumption of vulnerable families. The intervention will be complemented by a small-scale component of face-to-face, virtual, telephone and other training.

title.narrative: Support towards the ZCCB COVID19 Response Plan

description.narrative:
ZCCB has prepared a COVID-19 Multi-sectoral Response Plan in line with the National COVID-19 Multi-Sectoral Contingency and Response Plan, to guide Church’s (Catholic Church institutions) preparedness and response to the threat of COVID-19 in all the 11 dioceses. The purpose of this funding is to provide support to ZCCB to prepare for a coordinated COVID19 multi-sectoral response through the following (1)Provide risk communication information for COVID19 prevention and containment; and, (2) Capacity strengthening of front line health workers in Catholic health facilities and faith leaders on COVID19.
The COVID19 situation in Zambia worsened since the first wave that was recorded in March 2020. Incidences of new cases of COVID19 have escalated in both the number of confirmed cases and the number of deaths since the second wave of the new strain of COVID19. Unlike the first wave which was mild, this surge in cases was further accompanied by an increase in the severity of the disease requiring hospitalization and oxygen therapy. With the increased levels of COVID19, ZCCB has adapted and designed some activities that will help the Catholic Church to support communities to respond to the new COVID variant.

title.narrative: St Francis Community Integrated Care Programme Emergency Food Assistance project

description.narrative:
Due to the unprecedented drought of 2019 that impacted more than half of Zambia, the price of mealie meal (Zambia’s staple food) has been increasing every month due to the shortage of maize which was as a result of the crop failure. The rising food prices has had a particularly negative impact on the urban poor communities including those working with St. Francis. St. Francis’s target group mainly includes people with HIV and mental health challenges and the rising price of mealie meal has had a negative impact on these families who are now failing to have a meal a day. Inadequate food is leading to non- adherence to medication which in turn is likely to lead to regression in their physical/ mental health and possibly death. In addition to this drought related situation, the COVID19 threatens to exacerbate the health of our clients due to their weakened immune system.
This project aims to ensure that people living with HIV and Mental Health challenges have improved food security and are adhering to their drugs. The food provided is expected to help our Clients maintain proper adherence to their medication but also it will help them build a strong immunity which can help to prevent death in the event of infection from the coronavirus.

participating-org.narrative: St Francis Community Integrated Care Programme

receiver-org.narrative: St Francis Community Integrated Care Programme

title.narrative: Cancel Zambia's Debt to Free up Resources to Fight COVID19

description.narrative:
The World Health Organisation (WHO) declared the novel coronavirus outbreak, a global pandemic on 11th March 2020. Zambia has now been affected by the pandemic with 1,200 confirmed cases as at 8th May 2020 and 10 deaths. According to the risk analysis conducted by the Ministry of Health, the coronavirus has the potential to affect 7,616,108 people in 43 districts of the ten provinces of Zambia. The pandemic has also the potential to impact the economy of the country and ultimately the resources to provide on-going provision of essential goods and services as well as the resources to respond to COVID-19. The ease of response to COVID-19 is aided by strong and stable economic fundamentals.
With the COVID-19 pandemic government’s revenues has dropped as most businesses in various value chains have been adversely affected. Further, the demands to contain the outbreak of COVID-19 has also meant that the little revenue that the government is currently generating is being channelled to COVID-19 mitigation efforts. But clearly with a constrained treasury due to debt and dropping revenues, it is justifiable that a permanent relief mechanism is assured for countries such as Zambia.
Against this background, the Jesuit Centre for Theological Reflection (JCTR) in partnership with Caritas Zambia is seeking to bring about economic justice for the vulnerable and voiceless citizens of Zambia by influencing Zambia’s lenders to cancel some of its debt. It is hoped that this will free up resources for public service delivery particularly in the education, health and water and sanitation sectors. It is also envisioned that the reduced debt burden will increase the country’s ability to effectively and efficiently respond to the COVID-19 pandemic.

title.narrative: Youth Voices Forums taking the Voice of the Church Louder

description.narrative: CCJP is elevating the work on social accountability spearheaded by youth structures (dubbed Youth Voices Forums) that CCJP established, trained and moulded over the past years. In the past phase to April 2021, the project enhanced youth participation in decision making and meaningful dialogue between youth and respective powerholders/duty bearers in Chinhoyi Dioceses targets 3 communities. There is evidence of youth agency in influencing accountability by powerholders at varying levels, including at traditional governance. The current phase (May 2021- May 2023) learns from the past phase and adapts to emerging issues within the Covid context, aims at contributing to building of resilient communities in Chinhoyi Diocese. The project realises the role of peace building as an entry point to governance programming with lessons from the social accountability approach and explores integrating a livelihoods component in realisation of the interconnectedness of the political and social issues.

title.narrative: St Alberts Mission Hospital COVID-19 Emergency Response 2020

description.narrative: St Alberts Mission Hospital values the right to life and the Dignity of the person in its response to COVID 19, a global epidemic that is life threatening. The Hospital being a member of the ZCBC Health institutions and run by medical Missionaries who also belong to the family of CARITAS INTERNATIONALIS, and believe in totality to the dignity of the person and in reaching out to the most vulnerable has made an appeal for support in terms of PPE equipment to help the resource constrained Mission Hospital respond to COVID-19 effectively. The Hospital has a comparative advantage, for it strides across three provinces, namely Mashonaland West, Mashonaland Central and accessible by people from other provinces mainly Mashonaland East making it a prime port of call for the emergency response. It has a record for being people centred during the HIV and AIDS challenges in the country. The hospital prides itself for being able to work effectively with the communities as it had a pool of volunteers dedicated and trained to l be able to cascade accurate information in the communities on prevention, and case management. PREVENTION is their catch word where there is no cure and prevention is the way to go, social distancing, self-isolating and regular thorough washing of hands with soapy water or use of at least above 70% alcohol based hand sanitisers . Procurement of the PPE materials will go a long way in alleviating pain and suffering to Zimbabwean communities and at the same time giving confidence and assurance to the health care and ancillary staff who will be working on the frontline to dedicate themselves to serving the most vulnerable cases in the communities and presented at the hospital.

title.narrative: WASH COVID 19 Response Project “Improving Water, Sanitation and Hygiene in Rural Areas of Zimababwe"

description.narrative: The project aims to improve access to safe water, hygiene and sanitation practices and a means to practice good hygiene for people affected by the drought. This will be instituted by enhancing preparedness of the vulnerable population to minimize the spread of COVID-19; through critical social services provision in the area of WASH, including COVID-19 risk communication and awareness campaigns, remain essential and lifesaving. The intervention will enable continuation of health and hygiene promotion, and access to water supply services as well as provision of awareness messages on COVID-19 to rural communities mainstreaming GBV, disability and PSEA. Activities to be carried out include repair of water points/boreholes for safe water provision, distribution of hygiene kits, establishment of hand wash stations which are disability friendly, strengthening and establishment of health clubs, IEC material distribution, strengthening of Rural water and sanitation structures to coordinate, plan and monitor the COVID-19 Outbreak response activities, outreaches on COVID-19,GBV,PSEA and facilitating the establishment of a complaints and feedback mechanism to ensure accountability in the implementation of the whole project.

title.narrative: Water Supply for Mtawatawa Hospital -Covid Isolation Centre in UMP

description.narrative: This project is for one-off support to the Covid Isolation Centre in Mtawatawa Hospital UMP for water supply. The district raised a cry for help for water which is critical for handwashing in prevention of COVID. This will help save the lives of patients, hospital staff and the local communities in danger.

title.narrative: Support to farming communities at risk of being impacted by COVID 19 in Zimbabwe

description.narrative: The project is aimed at supporting drought affected farming communities at risk of being impacted by COVID 19 in Hwange district through the distribution of drought tolerant crop seed(cow peas and sorghum) to 2000 households and stock feed to 1272 households. In total 3272 households/small holder farmers will be supported. The project will be implemented in 7 wards of the district , 4 wards (5,6,7,8) will be targeted for crop seed intervention and 3 wards (12,13,20) for stock feed. To ensure effective targeting and hence increased access to supplementary stock feed and seed for summer plant to vulnerable farmer the project will work hand in glove with government extension workers (primarily Agritex), community leaders, project staff(CAFOD/Caritas). Beneficiaries selection includes willing vulnerable households with labour capacity or can be supported with community ,own at least 0.4ha of land for crop seed and household owning less than 4 herd of cattle for stock feed.60% targeted beneficiaries will be women.

title.narrative: Caritas Hwange Drought Response Project [ CIEA02/2020 Extention ]

description.narrative:
CARITAS Hwange is one of the diocèses that participated in the Emergency Appeal Drought Response Project [CIEA02/2020] which ran from January through to December 2020. The selection of Hwange district to participate in the project was informed by findings from the 2019 Zimbabwe Vulnerability Assessment Committee (ZimVAC) Rural Livelihoods Assessment and the CARITAS Zimbabwe National Rapid Food Security Assessment (October 2019). The 2 assessments confirmed Hwange’ s vulnerability status. Hwange district experienced long dry spells in December 2019 and January 2020, which was coupled with the early cessation of the rain season. This affected the crop production for the district. Household income and purchasing power had been further eroded by the poor macro-economic situation. Mid-season drought experienced in January to February 2020 resulted in more than 45% right off cereal crops especially maize (Agritex First Round crop Sample Survey report 2020). This resulted in reduction of low area planted. The advent of COVID-19, which led to the national lockdown from April 2020, exacerbated the situation for the rural communities in Hwange district. COVID-19 created a severe economic shock, mostly in the form of loss of income, particularly for the most vulnerable who depended on agriculture and remittances from relatives within and outside the country.
CARITAS Hwange started distributing food to selected households in Nemananga ward under the EA Drought response project in April 2020 up to August 2020. The distribution ended prematurely due to shortage of funds since the appeal was not fully funded, resulting in communities slipping back to food crisis. Nemananga ward is one of the wards near the Victoria Falls. The ward experienced an influx of people who relocated from Victoria Falls as a result of lock down induced retrenchments, especially those under the tourism sector. The targeted area therefore remains food insecure and in need of assistance.

title.narrative: Demystifying myths and misconceptions about Covid-19

description.narrative:
As of the 4th of March 2021, Zimbabwe had 36 223 COVID-19 confirmed cases, 33 632 recoveries and 1483 deaths and as of the 3rd of March there were 146 hospitalised cases. People continue to be infected and affected by COVID-19 on a daily basis. The project therefore seeks to raise awareness to all citizens through different media platforms, national papers, and radio stations.
SOCCOM would like to raise awareness on prevention, stigma and the vaccines and their processes. Working with the Ministry of Health and Child Care, the Health Commission, Caritas and the Education Commission, and also basing on information coming from the United Nations and the World Health Organisation, SOCCOM has discovered that there is need for continuous information on prevention according to the WHO standards, especially the issue of masking up, washing of hands, sanitisation and social distancing. The issue of vaccination is still a bone of contention among many people especially health workers according to the information obtained from hospitals. SOCCOM would therefore like to participate in the promotion of the vaccine. SOCCOM has found out that Coronavirus does not discriminate and everyone needs to be educated and informed about the Covid-19 and its side effects.
Covid-19 does not select and all people need to be equipped with education and information. The role of this project is to protect all people through provision of relevant information at all levels and for all age groups. All people are included in information dissemination through the use of the media available to them. The project is tailor made to include all citizens through the use of different media platforms.
